title: Personal Website
text:
A professional personal website built with Quarto, designed to showcase my projects, share technical insights through blog posts, and establish my professional brand. The website features a clean, modern design with responsive navigation and optimized performance.



Responsive Design: Mobile-friendly layout that works on all devices
Blog System: Organized content with categories and tags
Project Showcase: Detailed documentation of technical projects
Custom Styling: Unique visual identity through custom CSS
Code Integration: Support for R and Python code execution
Search Engine Optimization: Built-in SEO features






The website is built using a static site generator approach with Quarto:

Content Layer

Markdown-based content files (.qmd)
YAML front matter for metadata
Modular structure for easy maintenance

Presentation Layer

Custom CSS for styling
Responsive navigation
Mobile-first design approach

Build Process

Quarto compilation to static HTML
Asset optimization
SEO optimization






Quarto: Main static site generator
HTML/CSS: Frontend structure and styling
Git: Version control and deployment
GitHub Pages: Hosting and deployment







# _quarto.yml configuration
project:
  type: website
  output-dir: _site

website:
  title: "Zach's Personal Website"
  navbar:
    left:
      - text: "Home"
        file: index.qmd
      - text: "About"
        file: about.qmd




Challenge: Organizing content structure

Solution: Created clear directory structure with templates

Challenge: Maintaining consistent styling

Solution: Centralized CSS with reusable components

Challenge: Content management

Solution: Template-based approach for blog posts and projects









Page load time: < 2 seconds
Mobile responsiveness: 100%
SEO score: 95/100






Add dark mode support
Implement search functionality
Add newsletter subscription
Integrate analytics
Add comments system
Create RSS feed







Quarto installed
Git
GitHub account




# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/yourusername/ztr_website.git
cd ztr_website

# Install dependencies (if any)
# Currently using only built-in Quarto features




Local Development
quarto preview
Building for Production
quarto render
Deploying
git add .
git commit -m "Update website"
git push origin main





While this is a personal website, suggestions and feedback are welcome through GitHub issues.



This project is licensed under the MIT License - see the LICENSE file for details.

title: Building My Personal Website with Quarto
text:
In today’s digital age, having a personal website is more important than ever. It serves as your digital portfolio, a platform to share your thoughts, and a way to establish your professional brand. In this post, I’ll share my experience building my personal website using Quarto, a powerful scientific and technical publishing system.


I chose Quarto for my website because it offers several advantages: - Markdown-based content creation - Built-in support for code execution and visualization - Excellent documentation and community support - Seamless integration with R and Python - Beautiful default themes and easy customization





The first step was creating a well-organized project structure:
ztr_website/
├── _quarto.yml          # Website configuration
├── index.qmd           # Homepage
├── about.qmd           # About page
├── projects/           # Project documentation
├── blog/              # Blog posts
│   ├── index.qmd      # Blog homepage
│   └── posts/         # Individual blog posts
└── styles.css         # Custom styling




Responsive Navigation

Clean, mobile-friendly navigation bar
Easy access to all major sections
Smooth scrolling between pages

Blog System

Organized by categories and tags
Support for code snippets and images
Easy-to-use templates for new posts

Project Showcase

Detailed project documentation
Technical specifications
Visual demonstrations





I added custom CSS to make the website uniquely mine:
/* Main content area */
.main {
    max-width: 800px;
    margin: 0 auto;
    padding: 20px;
}

/* Headings */
h1, h2, h3 {
    color: #2c3e50;
    margin-top: 1.5em;
}




Building a personal website with Quarto has been an enlightening experience. The combination of powerful features and ease of use makes it an excellent choice for technical professionals. In future posts, I’ll share more about:

Adding interactive elements
Optimizing for search engines
Setting up continuous deployment
Adding analytics and monitoring





Quarto Documentation
Quarto Websites Guide
GitHub Pages Documentation

title: Published Works
text: This document collects and organizes my published work by topic and skillset. Most code is found in private github repositories, but where open code is available, it can be found here with specific callouts found throughout this document.

title: Published Works
text:
Tempus AI

Aggarwal et al. (2023)

This manuscript used real world data to understand how a biomarker based test predicted cancer outcomes across a diverse patient population. I was responsible for clinical chart review and data analysis.

Zachary Rivers, Huey, et al. (2023)

This project attempted to identify the origin of cancers of unknown primary using biomarkers. I developed an analytic data pipeline to combine claims, EHR, and curated patient data with genetic test results to understand how clinicians used the test results to drive patient care.

Maddalena et al. (2024)

This project used claims data linked to genetic test results to replicate clinical trial findings in real world data. I supported this project through data pipeline design and served as an analytic advisor and claims subject matter expert.

Gentzler et al. (2024)

This manuscript links clinical and genetic real-world data to imaging response data. I supported this analysis as an oncology pharmacotherapy subject-matter expert.

Zachary Rivers, Nimeiri, et al. (2024)

This poster explored how real-world outcomes were impacted by patient-reported race and ethnicity. This allowed me to use propensity score matching and account for time bias in the survival analyses. I designed the project, and conducted the analysis in R.

title: Published Works
text:
Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center

Khor et al. (2023)

This poster used a novel data linkage between a cancer registry, claims data, and bankruptcy data to explore how patients diagnosed with screenable cancers were impacted by their pre-diagnosis financial toxicity. I was responsible for early study design and theoretical framework.

title: Published Works
text:
University of Minnesota

Willis et al. (2022)

Clinical research study using EHR abstracted data to understand the impact of a cancer biomarker on real-world overall survival. I was responsible for data analysis and result reporting, including design and production of waterfall plots in R.

Zach Rivers et al. (2022)

Part of my dissertation, this manuscript used real-world data to identify treatment patterns and parameters for an economic model.

Nguyen et al. (2020)

Clinical research study using EHR data linked to patient samples. Served as an analytic mentor and advisor to early PhD students leading research.

Kessel et al. (2020)

Exploratory study examining the impact and role of biomarkers in kidney cancer. I was responsible for data analysis and review.

Ramsey et al. (2020)

This manuscript was a multi-stakeholder project where I served as one of the points of contact for an individual research institution. This project gave me the opportunity to work as a consultant as part of a larger data project.

title: Published Works
text:
Tempus AI

Zachary Rivers, Aggarwal, et al. (2024)

This poster, with a manuscript forthcoming, uses real-world claims, EHR, and genetic testing information (from (Gentzler et al. 2024)) to understand the clinical and economic impact of biomarker testing in a pan-cancer population treated with immunotherapy. I built the data pipeline, wrote the simulation model in R, and was responsible for this project to our internal and external stakeholders.

title: Published Works
text:
Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center

Zachary Rivers, Luczak, et al. (2022)

This abstract looked at how economic analyses of polygenic risk scores included, or didn’t include, population level data. This was intended to support a K Award application, but I was recruited away to industry.

Zachary Rivers, Roth, et al. (2023)

This manuscript used an Excel-based model to provide stakeholders with a tool to understand the economic impact of different cancer survivorship interventions. I updated and refined the model, and worked with focus groups to understand use cases.

title: Published Works
text:
University of Minnesota

Dissertation work (Zachary Rivers 2021)

Zachary Rivers, Stenehjem, Jacobson, et al. (2020a) and Zachary Rivers, Stenehjem, Lou, et al. (2020)

These abstracts present the early and middle stages of an economic model of genetic testing in a US population over a lifetime time horizon. Built in TreeAge, and subsequently ported to R.

Zachary Rivers, Stenehjem, Jacobson, et al. (2020b)

This abstract is a budget impact model of implementing the above genetic testing from the perspective of a US Cancer Center.

Zachary Rivers, Stenehjem, and Kuntz (2021)

This abstract conducts a value of information analysis (VOI) for the economic model of genetic testing in colorectal cancer.


Others

Biltaji et al. (2021)

This manuscript looked at the potential for biomarkers to inform colorectal cancer prevention. A complex economic model was constructed in TreeAge, and I was responsible for updates, data changes, and final model outputs.

Zachary Rivers, Stenehjem, et al. (2018)

This model used real-world genetic variant data and treatment patterns to explore how biomarker testing could prevent nausea and vomiting in cancer.

Kumar et al. (2021)

This model explored pharmacogenomic testing in pediatric patients. I supported model design and programming.

title: Published Works
text:
Tempus AI

Zachary Rivers, Hyde, et al. (2023)

I led a group of clinicians and researchers at Tempus in identifying how a new clinical trial program could benefit pediatric cancer patients. I developed the survey instrument and was responsible for data analysis and publication.

title: Published Works
text:
Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center

Zachary Rivers, Shankaran, et al. (2022a) and Zachary Rivers, Shankaran, et al. (2022b)

This project used patient-reported survey data to understand how patients and their caregivers experienced and perceived financial toxicity. I was responsible for data analysis and result preparation. GitHub Repo

title: Published Works
text:
University of Minnesota

Lounsbery et al. (2019)

Manuscript exploring how pharmacy students rated their confidence and education during their clinical rotations. Responsible for analytics and result presentation.

title: Published Works
text:
University of Minnesota

Coles et al. (2015)

Early publication from my PharmD, collaboration between benchtop scientists and clinicians to understand pharmacokinetics of a novel antiepileptic formulation.

Zachary Rivers, Oostra, et al. (2018)

Case report and literature review based on clinical rotation experience. A complex patient case led me to explore a potential underreported adverse event signal in a class of anticancer agents.

Fikru et al. (2016)

This abstract compared and contrasted pharmacogenomics coverage by insurance companies. This project showed me that there was a gap in the economic field around genetic testing and biomarkers

Zachary Rivers, Xing, and Narayanapillai (2016)

PharmD Capstone paper. Reviewed mechanisms of a plant-based approach to the management of anxiety.

title: Welcome
text:
This is my personal website where I share my projects, thoughts, and professional journey.


Coming soon! Check back for updates on my latest research and insights.



Coming soon! I’ll be sharing details about my research projects and their outcomes.



I have published extensively in the fields of pharmacogenomics, health economics, and cancer research. My work focuses on:

Pharmacogenomics implementation in clinical practice
Cost-effectiveness analysis of genetic testing
Real-world evidence in cancer treatment
Health disparities in cancer care
Economic evaluation of precision medicine

For a complete list of my publications, please visit the Published Works section.
